She has been in this business for the last year and she hopes to grow her retail shop to a big wholesale shop. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is lack of finances. However, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more general items to restock her store. She describes herself as ambitious.

loans.use: Flour, sugar, detergent and other general items for her store.

loans.name: Purity Wambui

texts.en:
Purity Wambui N. is a 20-year-old single woman who supports her father, mother, and younger sister. They live in Uthiru just a few kilometers from Nairobi. She owns a boutique where she sells clothes. She has been in this business for two years and earns a profit of Kshs.7,500 per month.

Purity has never borrowed from any other MFI and was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend. She is applying for a loan of Kshs. 20,000 to buy more clothes to sell in order to offer a variety of clothes to her customers. She plans to use the profit generated to venture into shoe selling.

In future she hopes to grow her business and open more outlets, and be able to distribute clothes to other sellers.

loans.use: To buy more stock of clothes for sale

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice W. is forty-eight years old.  She has two children whom she hopes to educate to the university level. She has a restaurant in a residential area in Nairobi known as Joski in which she serves the local people. She has been in the restaurant business for three years now and she says that the business is profitable; the major challenge she has is lack of finances. However, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. She hopes that in the future, she will grow her business into a hotel. She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy supplies for making food to sell to her customers. She describes herself as ambitious.

loans.use: Raw materials for her restaurant

loans.name: Arman

texts.en: Arman G. is married with one child. The family lives with Arman’s parents who are pensioners. Arman’s wife takes care of their child. Arman has been running a car seat and furniture upholstery renovation business since 1995. Currently he is using two old sewing machines at his rented small factory room. To revive the business Arman would like to replace the old sewing machines with new ones and get a large volume of good quality fabric. This will increase Arman’s profit by 25%.

loans.use: purchasing sewing machines and upholstery fabric

loans.name: Winny

texts.en:
Winny is a farmer from Kitale in western Kenya.  She is 37 years old and a single mother of four children who are between the ages of nine and eighteen. Three of the children are currently attending school. Winny has been farming for six years and employs one farmhand. Her farm produces milk, vegetables and maize which are all sold locally. She also earns income from her service as a dip attendant. Her primary challenge has been lack of enough animal feed.

She has requested this loan of 31,200KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will help her purchase a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. In the future, she plans to buy three dairy cows and a posho mill.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en:
Tabitha N., age 51, is a poultry farmer in a residential area in Nairobi. She raises and sells chickens to the local people. She has been in this business for two years now and she says that the business is profitable. Her primary challenge is the lack of sufficient finances. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

Tabitha's husband is a self-employed welder. They have three daughters and two sons, all of whom they hope to educate to the university level.

She will use her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more chickens to meet the high local demand for chicken. She hopes to diversify to a real estate business in future. She describes herself as ambitious.

loans.use: To buy chickens

loans.name: Man's Group

texts.en:
This is a small borrowing group of five members. Mrs. Man P., age 32, is the group leader. To earn a daily income, she sells grocery items from a small storefront in her house in the village. She is able to earn US $3.00 per day. Her husband is a board mender for local fishermen in his village and elsewhere. To increase her inventory of grocery items in order to better satisfy her customers, Man P. is requesting a loan to purchase more cooking ingredients and plastic goods for her store. 

The other four members of the group are: 

Mrs. S., a fish catcher, who is requesting a loan to buy more pigs.

Mrs. E., a fish catcher, who needs a loan to mend her house. 

Mrs. V., a fisherman, who is asking for a loan to purchase more wood for mending her house. 

Mrs. S., a grocery seller, is asking for a loan to buy more grocery items.

loans.use: To purchase more cooking ingredients and plastic goods for her store

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary, age 53, is a farmer from the town of Kitale in western Kenya. She has been farming for ten years and employs one farmhand. Her farm produces milk, eggs, vegetables, and maize, all of which are sold locally. Her biggest challenge has been a lack of sufficient animal feed.

She has requested this loan of 31,200 KES through Juhudi Kilimo in order to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The income from this loan will help her provide for the basic needs of her family. She plans to buy five dairy cows over the next five years and become the primary milk supplier to the local market.

Mary is the mother of four grown children.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis N., age 27, owns and operates a restaurant business. The business is located in a well-known open-air market in Nairobi called Gikomba. He has been in this business for four years. He says that this business is profitable. He says his primary challenge is that there are many other people in the area doing the same kind of business, which inhibits customer loyalty. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

He will be using his loan of Kes 50,000 to buy food items for making meals for his customers. He aspires someday to open a big restaurant in the town center. He also envisions buying a plot in which he will build his family house someday. He describes himself as hardworking and determined.

Francis and his wife have two small children. His wife stays at home to take care of them while Francis tends daily to his business in order to earn an income to support his family.

loans.use: To buy rice, flour, and other food items for making meals at his restaurant business

loans.name: Kamukamu Women's Group - Kyenjojo

texts.en:
Hardworking Resty S. is a married mother of five children. She has been running a tea-growing business in Kitoma, Kyenjojo, for more than 25 years. It all began when she bought a plantation garden of tea leaves and since then, she has been picking green tea leaves and selling them to the Mabale tea factory. She does this alongside sales from fresh foods like cassava and sweet potatoes. She makes 30,000 Ugandan shillings in a week.

For now, she is held back by poor yields and therefore, she is seeking a loan that will help her buy fertilizers for her to improve the quality of her land and her yields. This will, in the long run, help her get more sales revenue out of selling her tea leaves and she says she will be able to pay tuition fees for her university-going children. Kamukamu is the group she belongs to.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Benson

texts.en:
Benson M. N., age 22 and unmarried, sells music CDs at an open-air market in Nairobi known as Muthurwa. He has been in this business for one year now. He says that this business is profitable. His major challenge is that there are other people in the area doing the same kind of business, which inhibits customer loyalty. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

He plans to use his loan of Kes 50,000 to establish a new music shop from which he will be able to serve more customers. He hopes to develop this into a large, wholesale shop where he will sell CDs and musical instruments. He sees himself becoming a millionaire! He describes himself as hardworking, determined, generous, and kind.

loans.use: To establish a new, expanded music shop

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia O., age 58, grows and harvests assorted crops to offer for sale. Lilia has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. She and her husband have three grown children and live in the village of Dalumpinas, Sapang Dalaga.

In 2007, Lilia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services. She hoped to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Lilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. 

Lilia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will also be used as additional capital, this time toward her new business: she wants to open a grocery store. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Lilia from PMPC. 
   
About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as working capital for her new grocery store business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her poultry farm

loans.name: Minavar's Group

texts.en:
Minavar M., 53, is the leader of this group. She is 53 and married. Her spouse temporarily works in Russia. The family has two children--the son is also in Russia, the daughter is a schoolgirl. The main family incoming comes from cattle breeding. Seven years ago, Minavar sold potatoes in the market. With her earnings, she decided to purchase a cow, and since then she has been reselling cattle. The purpose of this loan is to buy another calf. In the future, the family wants to buy a flat in Osh city.

Muhabat A., 40, is the treasurer of the group. She is a widow who is raising three sons on her own. The eldest son is in the military and the other two are schoolboys. Muhabat makes money by selling fruits and vegetables. When she started her business 12 years ago, she sold cotton-seed oil. Out of her profits, she has managed to build a house. She will use her part of the loan to purchase a calf. In the future, she is planning to buy a car.

Ulanbek D., 21,  is a bachelor. In his childhood, he helped his father breed cattle. Now, for the past two years, he is breeding cattle on his own. He has earned sufficient money to build a temporary house. Ulanbek wants a loan to purchase a calf. In the future, he wants to marry and to buy an automobile.

Tynchtykbek T., 24, is married. His wife is a teacher. The family makes their living by cultivating tobacco and by reselling cattle. Since 2007, Tynchtykbek has been reselling livestock. His profits have enabled him to buy a lot. The loan purpose is to buy cattle. In the future, he is planning to build a house on his new lot.
	
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious, and socially focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members receive special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a calf

loans.name: Olympia

texts.en:
Olympia R., 55, is from the village of Rizalina, Rizal. She is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Olympia grows assorted crops to sell. Her main source of income comes from buying and selling copra (dried coconut). Olympia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Olympia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Olympia has successfully repaid her previous loan of 10,000 PHP. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Olympia is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used as additional working capital for the business. This loan will be Olympia's sixth loan from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It uses the Grameen model to reach out to the rural poor.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation. Because manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template which enables its field partners to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for buying copra

loans.name: David

texts.en: David M. K., 52, is married and has adult children. His wife stays at home to take care of the household chores while David works in his tire business at Racecourse road in Nairobi. He sells second-hand tires. He has been in this business for the last 15 years. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge is that there are other people in the area doing the same kind of business. He also lacks enough finances to grow his business. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of 50,000 KES  to buy more tires to sell. He hopes to grow his business and to start selling brand new tires. He also sees himself owning rental houses in future. He describes himself as hardworking, determined, and outspoken person who is always ready to help.

loans.use: Buy second-hand tires

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en: Anecita Danore is from the village of Bagacay, Sibutad. She is 51 years old and married with four adult children. To make a living, Anecita runs a grocery store. Anecita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2008, Anecita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anecita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. Anecita is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used as additional working capital for the business. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Anecita from PMPC. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for the business

loans.name: Anarkul's Group

texts.en: Anarkul U. is the leader of this group. She is 49 and married to a farmer. The family has three children: the eldest of them is working and the rest are school pupils. The family is engaged in cattle breeding. They are keeping cows and bulls and they make some profit selling dairy products. This business has been running for 10 years. During this time, Anarkul’s family has managed to obtain a house. With this loan, she wants to purchase a cow to raise and to further increase profits from selling dairy products. In the future, the family wishes to buy a house in Tokmok city and then to open their own milk factory. Shayirgul T., 30, is divorced. She has to bring up her kindergarten-going daughter alone. This mother raises money by selling fruits (apples, pears, peaches and grapes). She started her business 2 years ago, following her friend’s advice. The purpose of her loan is to increase the circulation of her commodities. In the future, Shayirgul intends to purchase a big house and then to open her own shop. Gulushkan A. is the group’s treasurer. She is 39, a widow. She takes care of two daughters: the elder one is a schoolgirl and the younger one takes preparatory lessons. This mother makes her living by working in a private lavatory. Out of her earnings, she has managed to widen her house and build an outhouse. The purpose of her loan is to purchase hardware in order to finish her house repairs. Gulushkan is aiming to give proper education to her daughters and also to open a trade outlet for selling foodstuffs. Elenora A., 26, is married. Her spouse raises money by working in a construction organization. The family is engaged in cattle breeding and sells meat products. With five years of working hard, they have managed to purchase a house and two cows. Elenora hopes to get a loan in order to buy a cow to sell dairy products. In the future, she is planning to obtain a flat in Bishkek city, then to increase her cattle stock. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Cornelia's Group

texts.en: Cornelia B. raises hogs to sell. She is 53 years old, married and has two grown-up children. She is from the village of Minlasag, Sibutad. Cornelia has been in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2008, Cornelia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Cornelia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. Cornelia is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her third loan from PMPC. Cornelia is the leader of a two member group accessing a loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group member if she is delinquent or defaults. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for hog raising

loans.name: Mutwa

texts.en: Mutwa N. is 43 years old and married to a casual laborer; they have five children aged between 8 and 24 and they hope to give them a good education to the university level. Mutwa N.'s business is located at Nguni, Mwingi and is served by Thika Branch, located in a region of Kenya known for the production of pineapples. She has been selling vegetables to the local people for the last two years. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is that she has to walk long distances to hawk the vegetables. However she works very hard to keep her business going well. She is using her loan of KES 10,000 to buy more vegetables to sell. She hopes to be a horticultural farmer to increase her stock of vegetables and expand her business. She describes herself as hardworking, innovative and responsible.

loans.use: to buy vegetables

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta C. is from the village of Landing, Baliangao. She is 56 years old, married and has 3 adult-aged children. Julieta owns and operates a business growing rice to sell. Julieta has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2004, Julieta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julieta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2,000 PHP from PMPC, which was used for personal purposes. Julieta is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used for rice production. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Julieta from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: for rice production

loans.name: May

texts.en:
May B. is from the village of Calaran, Calamba. She is 36 years old and married. She and her husband do not have any children. To make a living, May owns and operates a business making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. May B. has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, May joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. May is requesting her first loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase ingredients to make her products.
  
About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients

loans.name: Ainura's Group

texts.en:
Ainura I. is the leader of the group. She is 40 and divorced. She has to take care of her 2 children alone.  The elder daughter keeps house and the son is a schoolboy.  Ainura earns her living by working as an operator at the filling station “Aurdin”, she also makes money by selling bread on the market. Besides this she is planning to start cattle breeding (she now has 2 livestock animals). Her loan is to purchase 5 farm animals for increasing her number of cattle.  She will then be able to sell them and pay for her son’s education at university. Ainura’s intention is also to obtain a flat and provide a proper education for her son.

Toktobubu A., 58, is a widow with 3 children. The eldest son raises money by working as a loader, another one is a cattle farm worker, and the daughter is a house keeper. Toktobubu is a pensioner and her pension benefit is 32,000 soms per month. She is also engaged in cattle breeding. Out of her business profits she has managed to obtain an automobile and also to arrange her children’s weddings. Her loan purpose is to purchase 3 livestock animals. In future she is planning to increase her cattle stock and then to support her children financially.  

Venera S., 31, is married and her spouse is a seller. Currently the family is engaged in a business selling glassware. Past earnings made it possible for them to obtain furniture. The family hopes to get a loan in order to purchase goods for increasing their commodity circulation. In future Venera wants to buy a flat and also, together with her spouse, they are planning to give birth to a child.

Meerim Y., 26, is married. She has to bring up 2 children: the elder daughter goes to school and the younger son to kindergarten. Together with her mother, Meerim runs a business selling glassware. 5 years ago she received 10,000 soms from her mother and since that this kind of business has been the main source of income. The loan purpose is to purchase more goods for further resale. In the autumn Meerim wants to buy a house to give her children a good upbringing.

======================================
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.
 
Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit:  www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at  www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase farm animals for breeding

loans.name: Rutabo Twimukye, Kyenjojo Group

texts.en:
G. Didas, aged 42, is a gentle, hard working married father of 4 children. He has been operating a transport business for over two years where he rides a motorcycle as the most common and accessible means for transport for locals in the area. He reveals that he earns 50,000 Ugandan shillings on a weekly basis and that has helped him in undertaking the family responsibilities like educating his children and making other provisions.

As he plans on buying another motorcycle to expand his business, he hopes this loan will be of great assistance in implementing the above mentioned plan. Didas belongs to the Rutabo Twimukye group of members who hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.

loans.use: Purchase another motorcycle

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy W. N. is forty one years old and married. Her husband is employed by The Kenya Power and Lighting Company. They have three children aged eighteen, fourteen and ten years old.

Her business is located at an open air market known as Gikomba in Nairobi. She has been selling materials to passersby and the local tailors who use the materials for making clothes. She has been in this business for the last five years now. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is fluctuating market prices hence selling her products at low prices. She also faces a lot of competition from the local people. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well.

She is using her loan of 50,000 KES to buy more materials to expand her business and meet the demand of her customers. She hopes to grow her business and be able to import materials for reselling. She also sees herself building rental houses in the future. She describes herself as a hardworking and happy lady.

loans.use: Materials

loans.name: Burulkan's Group

texts.en:
Burulkan A. is the group’s leader. She is 58 years old and married. Her husband is a pensioner. The couple has brought up 6 children, all of whom are already grownups and live separately from their parents. The family's main income is from farming. For twenty years they have managed to improve their financial position, educate their sons and organize their children's weddings. Their cattle stock has also increased. This loan's purpose is to purchase 8-9 livestock animals for fattening and breeding. In the future, Burulkan and her family intend to build a house, to develop their business and to obtain an automobile. 

Kasmaaly O., 25, is married. His family has 2 children of preschool age. As the head of the family, he raises funds by being a taxi-driver, and is planning to start his own business reselling cereals and potatoes (he has 5000 soms in cash and 1000 kg of potato). He is requesting this loan to purchase 3000 kg of potato (6 soms per kilogram) for further resale. Kasmaaly wants to increase his commodity circulation and to improve his financial position. 

Zinakul M., 48, is married. Her spouse is a farmer. The family has four sons, the eldest of whom are students and the youngest of whom are school pupils. Farming has the main family business since 1994. During the years, they have worked hard and have managed to improve their financial position and to increase cattle stock. The purpose of the loan is to pay harvest service. In the future, Zinakul is planning to obtain an automobile and then to obtain a lot near Bishkek.

Alym I. is the treasurer of the group. She is 57 and married. Her family has 7 children. The eldest of them live separately from parents and one of their sons and his family live with the parents. Their youngest is a schoolboy. The family makes its money on field work. They started farming in 1994, after obtaining a lot, and began to cultivate the land. Through the years they have managed to improve their financial position, to purchase several cars and also to arrange their son’s wedding. The purpose of the loan is to buy petroleum-based fuels. In the future, Alym is planning to increase her cattle stock, and then to buy a lot near Bishkek.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is the treasurer of Dove Group which is being funded by Juhudi Kilimo. She is a farmer from the town of Kitale in western Kenya and has employed one farmhand. Her farm produces maize, milk, beans and vegetables, which are sold to the local market. She also runs a posho mill and a tailoring shop in the same area.

Grace is 46 years old. She is a widowed mother of four school-aged children, all of whom attend school.

She has requested this loan of 31,200KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The proceeds from the sale of milk will enable her to pay school fees for her children and feed her family well. Her primary challenge has been poor prices for her products. She however hopes that in the future she will expand her farming by buying 5 more dairy cows, for which she has enough land.

She is requesting Juhudi to also provide school fee loans.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Rezyl

texts.en:
Rezyl C. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 24 years old. Rezyl is married and has three young children. She is involved in farming and hog-raising. She plants and harvests rice crops to sell. She grows pigs for fattening. She says she works extra hard because her kids will soon be going to school. She hopes to be able to sustain her family's needs and her children's education.

Rezyl joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rezyl has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Rezyl is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase feed and fertilizers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase feed and fertilizers

loans.name: Teresiah

texts.en:
Teresiah W. has been making and selling the candy snacks that children like so much. They are made out of sweet corn. Most of her customers are primary-school pupils. She has done this business for seven years, with a profit margin of 10,000 Kenyan shillings (Kshs).

W.'s business location is in the Baba Dogo estate, which is highly populated with low-income earners, just few kilometers from the Nairobi City center. 

She is married to Justine and together they have three children, aged 12, 9 and 2 years. She has never borrowed from any other MFI (microfinance institution) and was introduced to KADET LTD by an existing client of KADET. She is applying for her first loan of Kshs 20,000 to buy more corn to make more of this candy snack to sell to the children.     

She hopes to grow her business and give her children the best education.

loans.use: To buy more corn to make candy snacks

loans.name: Zinakan Kydyrmanova's Group

texts.en:
Zinakan K. is the leader of the group. She is 53 and married. Her husband is a farmer. Zinakan makes her bread by offering a sewing service. She has been doing this for 12 years already, owing to the fact that she has vocational education. Due to years of working hard, she has managed to obtain multi-logic sewing-machines. The family wants to use this loan to purchase fertilizers for farming. In the future, they are planning to send a son abroad, then to purchase a car.

Sveta A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 46 and married. Together with her spouse, she brings up a son who is a schoolboy. Sveta works in the hospital and her husband is a builder.Out of their business profits they have managed to pay for the education of their children. In order to put money into agricultural development, the family hopes to get a loan. In the future, Sveta is planning to purchase a car and to arrange her son’s wedding. 

Rahat O., 28, is not married. She earns her living by working as a kitchen worker in a café. Her total earnings made it possible for her to begin house repairs. In order to finish it up, she needs to get a loan. In the future, Rahat is going to begin building a house. 

Kaken A. is 62 and a widow. She has been engaged in farming and agriculture for eight years already. During this time, she managed to arrange her children's weddings. The loan's purpose is to purchase petroleum-based fuels. In the future, Kaken wants to build a big house. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (remaining environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Kung

texts.en: Kung S. is a 25-year-old married woman who currently lives in the best territory of Phnom Penh Capital, in Cambodia. She and her husband are local chefs who work at a Korean restaurant. This young couple has been married for many years, but they still have no children yet. Kung said that her neighbor wants to sell a piece of farmland for a reasonable price, and that it is a good time to add to her assets. She will gain extra income by renting out this farmland to other farmers for a fee. For this reason, Kung would like a loan of $1000 in order to purchase this piece of farmland.

loans.use: To purchase a piece of farmland

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en: Rachel is 30 years old. She is married to a businessman. They have five children between the ages of six and 25. One of her children goes to school. The others don’t go to school, because they completed their primary level and she cannot afford to pay the school fees for them at the secondary level. Rachel sells beer and soft drinks. With the loan she will buy more beer and soft drinks to sell. Her business is known, and she would like to own a large stock of beer as a distributor. With the profit she will pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy more beer and soft drinks to sell

loans.name: Rochelle

texts.en:
Rochelle C. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 41 years old. Rochelle is married and has two children. She is involved in farming and has been planting and harvesting rice crops for quite some time now. She also raises pigs, but focuses on farming. Rochelle wants to save for her children's education, which is why she works extra hard. She also wants to improve her family's living conditions.

Rochelle joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rochelle has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Rochelle is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase feeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: To purchase feeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Abdallah

texts.en: Abdallah is 30 years old and single. He is a motorist. He has spent three years in the business of transporting people. With the loan, he will buy another motorbike for transport. His business is very well-recognized and accepted by the community, because he is used to transporting them. With the profit, he will renovate his house. He would like to own his own motor vehicle, instead of a motorbike.

loans.use: To buy another motorbike

loans.name: Ntungamo Tukore Twetugure B, Kihihi Group

texts.en: N. Edward, age 60, has been running an agriculture enterprise for over 20 years, and is still at his best proving to fellow agriculturalists in the area that he can make it. Having been inspired by close friends and good market prices for quite some time, hardworking Edward got a vision to grow bananas and coffee and also to venture into livestock farming. He has been farming in Nyakirehe, Kihihi, earning 240,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis out of his produce sales. The main drawback is harvesting low quantities and therefore, with this loan, he will purchase agricultural inputs like manure and more coffee seedlings. This will make it possible for him to get more output and to earn more revenue to care for his family of eight children and a wife at home. It will go further towards his goal of expanding his business and educating his children who are still in school.

loans.use: Purchase farm inputs like manure

loans.name: Tomas

texts.en:
Tomas S. is from the town of Sto. Niño. He is 34 years old, married and has three children. To make a living, Tomas plants and harvests rice for sale. Tomas works hard to provide income for his family and have savings in case of emergencies. 

Tomas joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. Tomas has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Tomas is requesting a new loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos which will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a member of Provider Group of Faulu Kenya. He runs his business in an open space, where he makes tea, doughnuts, eggs and samosas. He has been in the business for four years and has managed to employ two people. Being a member of Faulu Kenya, he has been trained on how to keep business records. He hopes to have a stable business in the future. He has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy a boiler and two kettles. In five years, he wants to own and run a hotel.

loans.use: To buy a boiler and two kettles

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes L. is currently in the business of selling bread and is requesting a loan to stock more baking flour, to make more bread to sell. Agnes is 25 years old and is married to a husband who is a farmer. She has three children, and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: To stock more baking flour

loans.name: Vanessa Jireh

texts.en:
Vanessa Jireh C. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 21 years old and married. She has one child, who is now one year and six months old. She grows pigs and farms for a living. Her pigs are for fattening and sold at the market. She plants and harvests rice crops for consumption and sale. Vanessa does her best to help provide for her family.

Vanessa Jireh joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vanessa Jireh has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Vanessa Jireh is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase farm supplies and livestock feeds. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies and livestock feeds

loans.name: Bernaflor

texts.en:
Bernaflor C. is from the village of Salay, Misamis Oriental. She is 23 years old and single. To make a living, Bernaflor owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling bananas and coconuts in the local community. Bernaflor has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Bernaflor joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bernaflor is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional bananas and coconuts to sell. This loan will be the first taken out by Bernaflor from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional bananas and coconuts to sell

loans.name: Ntungamo Tukore Twetungure A, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
Hard working, dependable and die-hard agriculturalist Alice K., 53, has been maintaining a banana plantation alongside her teaching profession for more than 10 years in her home area of Kyabuyorwe, Kihihi. She fetches an average amount of 200,000 Ugandan shillings per month from banana sales, though not enough to sustain her extended family.

Alice has persevered to keep the enterprise growing, and her aim for taking up this loan is to enable her to buy mulches and manure for the plantation as she looks at an expansion plan for transporting her products to bigger markets. This will help her increase productivity as well as earn more revenue, live a more sustaining life and educate all her children.

loans.use: To purchase mulches for the plantation

loans.name: Timap Bifo Group

texts.en: In the photo are members of the Timap Bifo Group. They run small-scale businesses in Makeni, a city in Northern Sierra Leone. This is not the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of previous SMT/Kiva loans, these entrepreneurs were able to expand their businesses, make more profit and give better support to their families. The leader of this group is Kadiatu S.. Kadiatu, age 29, was born in Kono, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. Currently, she is residing in Makeni together with her husband and two children. Her husband works for the National State Lottery and her children are attending secondary school. For many years now, Kadiatu has been selling locally dyed clothes called gara lappers. With her share of this loan, she will buy gara lapper making materials: inks, caustic soda, powder and white cotton cloth, in order to produce more gara cloths to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy gara lapper making materials: inks, caustic soda, powder, and white cotton cloth

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna L. is from the village of Talon, Gingoog City. She is 51 years old. Lorna is separated from her spouse and has one adult-aged child. To make a living, Lorna owns and operates a business venture raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting, trading and selling bananas, cassava and copra (dried coconut meat) in the local community. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lorna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to rent land to raise additional crops. This loan will be the third taken out by Lorna from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To rent land to raise additional crops

loans.name: Julius

texts.en: Julius is 45 years old, married and blessed with six children. He lives with his family in Kibera slums. He has a food stall made of iron sheets where he prepares food. He says that he gets a number of customers in the morning and evening. In addition, he rents out rooms in the slums so as to boost his income. Julius is a man who believes in hard work, and he is looking forward to building permanent rental houses in the future. He joined Faulu Kenya in 2007 under Kangwana group, where he is the treasurer. He really appreciates Faulu Kenya for the financial support. Through this, he has been able to add stock to his business. He has requested 80,000 Kenyan shillings to increase his stock of ingredients.

loans.use: To increase stock of ingredients

loans.name: Joice

texts.en: Joice J. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste in the custom market in Juba, and is requesting a loan to stock more groundnut to make paste to sell. Joice is 32 years old and is married. Her husband is a policeman. She has one child, who does not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy land.

loans.use: To stock more groundnuts for making paste to sell

loans.name: Lovely

texts.en:
Lovely C. is from the village of Molugan, El Salvador, Misamis Oriental. She is 32 years old. Lovely is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Lovely owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling ready to wear clothing and shoe products, and also dealing Natasha and Avon products in the local community. Lovely has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lovely joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lovely is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Lovely from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nhor

texts.en: Nhor S. is a 27-year-old mother of two teenage children who are currently in school. She is a garment worker in Phnom Penh City and has a proper salary each month. She has been working in her job since 2008. She has a life partner in her husband (Mr. Sophat) who works as controller of trackman and he always works in the construction field in order to check all the staff who drive trucks during working hours. Nhor S.’s husband presently earns an income of approximately $6.66 a day. He thinks that his company always spends money for oil and diesel oil. So he will sell diesel oil to the company in order to earn extra income to support his family. Nhor S. hopes to encourage her husband to earn more income, but she has no cash to make that possible. So, she is requesting a loan to purchase diesel oil in bulk for her husband to sell.

loans.use: To purchase diesel oil in bulk for her husband to sell.

loans.name: Lorina

texts.en:
Lorina E. is from the village of San Simon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 66 years old and married. To make a living, Lorina owns and operates a business venture raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs, goat and other cattles for sale. Lorina has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Lorina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Lorina is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Lorina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

location.town: San Simon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Kalagala Development - Mpigi Group

texts.en:
N. Annet has been relentless and pertinacious in her self-willed determination to make something invaluable out of her dual farming and poultry business undertakings, which took root 10 years ago. Her business is located in Mpambire - Mpigi. She started this business after she got financial assistance from an international non-governmental organization. Before this, Annet, a mother of three kids and six dependants, was more inclined towards subsistence farming. Her unwavering resolve has seen her make many inroads in terms of attracting clients, going about her business in an organised way, and making steady profits. These inroads have also been manifesting themselves in improved standards of living for her family. 

Her business accrues 100,000 shillings a week. She is requesting a loan to purchase rice in bulk, which she will resell at length in wholesale bags, not by the kilos as for retail. She makes common cause with Kalagala Development Group - Mpigi.

loans.use: To purchase rice in bulk for resale

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty W. is currently in the business of selling various items in a shop and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, etc., to sell.  Betty is 35 years old and is married to a farmer. She has five children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy land.

loans.use: To stock more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, etc., to sell

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is a 34-year-old married man with two children. He has been selling fish for two years in Nairobi City center after moving his business from a different city. His business is located in a very competitive area. He says that he has learnt a lot from the training offered by Faulu Kenya. He has learnt how to manage his business in a better way and has become more focused.  

He has requested 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy fish and fish products. He sees himself opening two more outlets for his business so that he may employ at least ten people.

loans.use: To buy fish and fish products

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
Amelita P. is from the village of Barangay 4, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 38 years old. Amelita is widowed and has 6 school-aged children. She owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells food & daily-use products. Amelita has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Amelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Amelita successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Amelita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn M. is from the village of Pigsag-an, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 54 years old, married and has 4 adult children. Merlyn owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells food & daily-use products and also retails rice. She has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Merlyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Merlyn is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Merlyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital

location.town: Pigsag-an, Cagayan De Oro City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Luzminda

texts.en:
Luzminda B. is from the village of Villa Verde, Balulang. She is 52 years old. Luzminda is separated from her spouse and has 4 adult children. She owns & operates a specialized retail store where she sells a variety of dried fish. She has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Luzminda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional dried fish to sell. Luzminda is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Luzminda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital

location.town: Villa Verde, Balulang, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Ori

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana A. is from the village of Canitoan, Lingating, Baungon, Bukidnon. She is 75 years old. Susana is widowed and has 8 adult children. She owns & operates an agricultural business, planting & harvesting cashew nuts for sale. Susana has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Susana joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Susana is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to rent land to raise additional crops. This will be her 5th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to rent land to raise additional crops

loans.name: Aldar

texts.en: Aldar H. is 36 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in the Bayanhoshuu district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her two sons both attend a local secondary school. Her husband operates a clothes retail trading business in a stall at the Uguuj market while Aldar operates a business selling flour and rice. She has been selling products of the Altan Taria Company since 1998 and has built a sustainable and successful operation. In 2002, she and her husband managed to expand their business and start selling a variety of clothes in the local community. Aldar is a very modest and hardworking businesswoman and says, "I am planning to build a house where our family will live in the future" She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase winter clothes for her family business in order to increase their working capital.

loans.use: To purchase winter clothes

loans.name: Knowledge Resource Center-Bushenyi Group

texts.en:
Hard working A. Joan, age 32, is a married mother of four kids between 14 and 6 years old. She has been operating a retail shop selling general products for home use from Nyakabirizi trading centre in Bushenyi. She started this business seven years ago upon realizing the ready market in the area and at the end of every week she is able to pocket profits to the tune of 40,000 Ugandan shillings. 

Her main challenge has been not having enough stock in her business to match the purchasing rate of the customers. She is therefore seeking a loan that she says will help her stock more general merchandise retail goods to satisfy the customers’ high demand and transform her enterprise into a big enterprise.
 
Being very committed to the business with good customer care, she hopes to increase her sales revenue. This will bring about a transformation in her business as she hopes to build a family house, achieve a self-sustaining life and take care of her children’s education expenses. She belongs to the Knowledge Resource Center Group-Bushenyi.

loans.use: To buy more stock for resale

loans.name: Alhamdulilai Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the “Alhamdulilai” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of SLL 800,000 for each. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and, consequently, improve their living conditions. 

Fatu B. (pictured in the back row on the left) is the leader of this group. The 55-year-old is married to a tailor and they have six children who are now grownups. Fatu has been a businesswoman for many years. She sells fried cakes, palm oil, groundnuts, etc. With her share of this loan, she will buy bags of flour and gallons of oil in order to fry more cakes. She will also buy gallons of palm oil and bags of groundnuts to add to her current ones.

loans.use: To buy flour, oil, palm-oil and groundnuts

loans.name: Oyunbat

texts.en: Oyunbat B. is 45 years old and lives with her husband and son in the bayanhoshuu of Ulaanbaatar: Mongolia's capital city. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in a rented yard. Her husband works in his brother's business and earns 200,000 MNT per month. Oyunbat has been operating a by-product trading business since July 2010, in a rented space at the shop. In the future, she would like to own her own house and fence where she can live with her family. Oyunbat is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase more by-products to increase her working capital.

loans.use: To purchase more by-products

loans.name: Laneh Kuru Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Lane Kuru” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are petty-businesspeople who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, in order to seek a loan of SLL 1,000,000 for each member of the group. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit and, consequently, improve their living conditions. 

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Mohamed K. who is pictured on the right. Mohamed was born in the village of Kamalo in northern Sierra Leone 65 years ago. He is married and has six children. His wife is a trader. Three of his children are attending primary school, two are in secondary school and one is in college.

For many years now, Mohamed has been making a living by selling Kola nuts. With his share of the loan, he will buy bags of Kola nuts to add to his business.

loans.use: To buy bags of Kola nuts to add to his business

loans.name: Tsend-Ayush

texts.en: Tsend-Ayush B. is 44 years old and lives with her husband and 3 year old daughter in Bayanhoshuu of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her daughter, aged 3, is not yet of school age and stays at home. Tsend-Ayush and her husband operate a taxi service. She started driving a taxi in 2003 using her own Excel car. After several successful years, she used her earnings to buy a new car after selling her outdated one. With the business profits, they were able to build a new house in their yard. In the future, they plan to build a garage for their car. Tsend-Ayush is a very clever woman and says, "I want to decorate our house". She is requesting a 700,000 MNT loan to purchase spare parts and to build a garage for her car.

loans.use: To purchase car parts

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en: Nicholas is 35 years old, married and has two children. He supplies meat to butcher shops and hotels. He started his business 10 years ago. Through Faulu Kenya, he has learnt how to manage his business finances. He has requested 40,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more meat to meet customer demand. He wants to own a big meat supply company in the future.

loans.use: To buy more meat

loans.name: Ndula

texts.en:
Ndula R. is married and has one child whom he supports. Ndula was introduced to KADET by world vision staff. He is applying for his first loan and has never borrowed from any other Micro-Finance Institution. 

He has been in the livestock trade for ten years. He plans to use this loan to purchase more livestock to raise and sell later at a profit. His business is located in a busy open-air market with a high population. Hence he has many customers.
 
Ndula wants to grow his business. With the extra profits, he plans to open a butchery in the future and very much hopes to become a great businessman. He describes himself as innovative.

loans.use: to purchase more livestock.

loans.name: Tsogtgerel

texts.en:
Tsogtgerel N. is 45 years old and lives with his wife and four daughters in Uvs province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in their own ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in a rented yard. All of his daughters attend the local school while his wife is currently unemployed due to health problems. She receives a disability pension of 56,000 MNT per month. 

Tsogtgerel works as a carpenter in his home, producing a variety of wood products. He has been engaged in this business for the past ten years and has made quality, unique furnishings for the people of his town. His monthly income is 300,000 MNT approximately. He works hard to expand his business so that he can purchase his own fence in the future. In the 10 years of owning his business, Tsogtgerel has gained much experience and knowledge in making quality furniture products. He is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to buy more timber and an ornament making machine.

loans.use: To buy more timber and an ornament making machine

loans.name: Charles Mburu

texts.en:
Charles has been operating his motorbike in Naivasha town for transport for the last two years. He is 32 years old and married to Jane Wangeci. They have one child.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the loan amount to renew the insurance coverage for his motorbike.

In the future, Charles hopes to have a fleet of taxis operating in Naivasha town.

loans.use: To renew insurance for his motorbike

loans.name: Kara Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Kara” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 1,200,000 for each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Aminata K. who is pictured on the left. Aminata is age 45 and was born in Makeni. She is married with four children. Her husband is a teacher and her children are attending both primary and secondary schools, respectively.  

For many years now, Aminata has been selling cloths, including gara lappers (locally dyed clothes), dishes and rubber bowls. She will use her share of this loan to expand her business. She will buy gara lapper making materials like inks, caustic soda, powder, white cotton cloths, dishes and rubber bowls to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy gara lapper making materials like inks, caustic soda, powder, white cotton cloths, dishes and rubber bowls to add to her business

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela is 38 years old. She is married and blessed with three children. For a living, she sells fish. She was previously selling grains for a living. Pamela also sells vegetables to earn extra income. In her business, she has employed one person.  

She has managed to expand her business, hence raising her living standards through Faulu Kenya. She hopes to venture into another business in five years. With the loan of 60,000 Kenyan shillings, she will buy tomatoes, cabbages and fish.

loans.use: To buy tomatoes, cabbages and fish

loans.name: Tamarsu Group

texts.en:
Kadie M. (pictured on the left) is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Kadie was born in Makeni city about 30 years ago. She is married to a miner and the couple has four children: two are in primary school and two are not of school-going age. For many years, Kadie has been selling rice, palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), vegetable oil, fish, etc. 

This is the first loan that Kadie and her group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and, consequently, improve their living conditions. 

Kadie will use her share of the loan (SLL 800,000) to expand her business. She will buy rice, palm oil, vegetable oil, fish, etc. in large quantity to add to her current stock.

loans.use: To buy rice, palm oil, vegetable oil, fish, etc. in large quantity to add to her current stock

loans.name: Beatrice Auma

texts.en:
Beatrice B. is 27 years old and has four children between 3 and 7 years old. She is married to Ezekiel B.. 

Beatrice has a hotel (a mini restaurant) that she has been running for the past three years. She is applying for her third loan from KADET LTD and has a good credit history with KADET. Her monthly income comes to 18,000 Kenyan shillings per month. She intends to use the money to buy some utensils and cooking ingredients for her hotel. The profits made will basically be used to pay school fees for her children and to cater for the family needs.

Her hopes and dreams are to see her business grow and to open another hotel in the neighboring town.

loans.use: Buy utensils and cooking ingredients

loans.name: San Vicente Group

texts.es:
San Vicente se denomina este comité integrada por señoras que trabajan de manera organizada ya dentro del segundo ciclo del Programas Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras.
Todas se encuentran muy contentas de formar parte del comité, y aseguran que seguirán trabajando para fomentar el grupo.
Una de las integrantes es  la Sra. Liz S. tiene quien tiene  30 años, con  3  hijos, su actividad principal es su copetín que tiene en el puerto Fenix, prepara almuerzo a las personas que trabajan en el puerto.
Ella es una señora muy  dedicada a su trabajo por no hacerle faltar nada a sus hijos, cuenta con el apoyo de su marido que esta con ella en el copetín.
Solicita el préstamo para renovar las herramientas de trabajo que ella utiliza para la elaboración de los comestibles, como sartenes, ollas, y cubiertos.
texts.en:
San Vicente is a co-op, and they are in their second cycle with the Women Entrepreneurs Committee. All the members are happy to be a part of the group and they pledge to continue working to keep the group strong.

One of the members Mrs. Liz S. is 30 years old with three children. Her primary business is a food stand that she runs in the Fenix port. She makes lunches for the people who work at the port. 

She is dedicated to her work and determined that her children will not want for anything. She works alongside her husband at the food stand. She will use her portion of the loan money to purchase the tools she needs to make her meals like pans, pots, and silverware.

loans.use: Purchase of cookware like pans and pressure cooks to use in the elaboration of food.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. is 34 years old and a widow with six children. They live in the Nyamasare area in the outskirts of Migori town.

Mary sells shoes in an open-air market. She was introduced to KADET by a friend who is also a client there. She is applying for her first loan of 15,000 KES to enable her to buy more shoes to add to her stock.

Mary’s profits will basically be used to pay school fees for her children and her family's wellbeing. Her hopes and dreams are to expand her business and even open up a shoe shop instead of sitting out in the sun to run her business.

loans.use: To buy more shoes to add to her stock

loans.name: Chuluunbaatar

texts.en:
Chuluunbaatar B. is 28 years old and lives with his daughter in Umnugobi province, Mongolia. He and his daughter live together in a traditional Mongolian tent home called a ger. His daughter attends a local kindergarten.

Chuluunbaatar has a studio where he produces a variety of paintings and sculpture. He has been engaged in this business since 2000 with the help of his father, B., and he has since built a stable and successful operation. Over the years, he has gained a lot of experience as an artist and has greatly improved his quality of life. He has used his earnings to build a workplace in his yard as well as to decorate his home.

In the future, he wants to expand his business and study to become an art teacher to instruct children how to paint pictures. He is planning to open his own exhibition during the end of October in his town. In November, he hopes to participate in an exhibition that will be held in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city.

Chuluunbaatar says, "For artists, the exhibition is the best way and biggest chance to sell their art." He is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase necessary materials and supplies in order to create more paintings and sculptures that will be exhibited in his own gallery opening in November.

loans.use: To purchase necessary materials and supplies

loans.name: Dominic

texts.en:
Dominic M. is 32 years old and a father of four children: Humprey, 9; Chris, 7; Rebecca, 4; and Lucy, who is 7 months old. His wife is Susan Robi and she sells vegetables to help support the family.

Dominic is in the transport business with a motorcycle. He is applying for his first loan from KADET LTD after being introduced by a fellow client. He is in need of buying spare parts for his motorcycle and the loan will come in handy to help him out. He intends to use the profits to cater to his family's needs.

His hope and dream is to build a permanent house for his family as they are currently living in a mud-thatched house.

loans.use: Buy motorcycle spare parts

loans.name: We All Na One Group

texts.en:
These are small-scale businesswomen in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to seek a loan of SLL 4,100,000 to enable them expand their businesses. With a loan of SLL 4,100,000, they will be able to add more stock to their businesses, make more sales, and more profit.
